awd_titl_txt: NanoEngineered Concrete Internal Conditioning for Targeted Suppression of Alkali-Silica Reaction
awd_abstract_narration:
Alkali-silica reaction (ASR) is a major deterioration mechanism causing significant expansion, cracking and damage to concrete material in service. Inspired by immunization and targeted therapy in cancer treatment, targeted suppression of ASR is the focus of this research. The existing mitigation methods are primarily targeted at single ASR prerequisites with limited efficiency and potential negative impacts on concrete performance. The primary objective of this project is to uncover the side-effect free mitigation of ASR, and then use the insights gained to guide the design of highly durable and sustainable infrastructure materials with unprecedented properties. A state-of-the-art methodology will be used by bridging the gaps between nanoengineering and cement chemistry to convert nanostructure of ASR gels to prevent volume expansion and cracking. This will lead to resilient and durable concrete thereby extending the lifetime of infrastructure and reducing the repair and maintenance costs. Overall, the acquired knowledge from this research effort will reduce the economic and societal impact of infrastructure deteriorations by providing insights for degradation preventions and service-life extension of new and existing concrete structures. The university's STEM program will be exploited to involve students in K-12 level as well as students at the undergraduate level.

Nanoengineered internal conditioning of concrete material triggered by multifunctional clay nanoparticles will be exploited based on a combined thermodynamic modeling and experimental approach. A fundamental understanding of the role of the nanoengineered internal conditioning in cement hydration that can suppress formation of ASR will be investigated. The research will focus on four research thrusts at: 1. Clay level: to functionalize clay nanoparticles to improve their dispersion, reactivity and tunable functions for internal conditioning; 2. Cement level: to tailor hydration behavior, pore network, and both solid and liquid compositions; 3. ASR level: to suppress ASR formation which prevents volume expansion and cracking; and 4. Concrete level: to improve durability-related mechanical and physical properties, and resistance to multiple aging mechanisms with a goal to design truly sustainable, resilient, and durable concrete material. The success of this project would be instrumental in advancing resilience-based and problem-oriented concrete material design through nanoengineering and thermodynamic means to stratify the quality requirement and performance expectation of future infrastructure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Alkali-silica reaction (ASR) poses a significant threat to concrete structures, leading to irreversible volume expansion, cracking, and extensive damage, resulting in substantial maintenance costs. Similar to the side effects of cancer treatments, conventional ASR mitigation methods can adversely impact concrete properties. To address this challenge, it is crucial to explore mitigation strategies that simultaneously address multiple ASR prerequisites and mechanisms. This research project focuses on a novel nanoengineered internal conditioning (NIC) technology. Through a combined thermodynamic modeling-experimental approach, the study aims to suppress ASR selectively without compromising concrete performance. Key project outcomes include:

(i) Two clay minerals, sodium montmorillonite (sMT), and metakaolin (MK) were functionalized with two nonionic surfactants in aqueous solutions through an ion-exchange method. This process resulted in increased basal spacing and water uptake capacity. Enhanced dissolution of Al and Si from clay particles into concrete pore solutions, coupled with elevated calcium hydroxide consumption capacity, was observed. The study found that the functionalized sMT exhibited increased reversible swelling behavior, making it an ideal internal curing (IC) agent. This enhanced swelling also facilitated ASR mitigation by providing additional space for the deposition of ASR gels, reducing internal stress, healing micro-cracks, and creating short-range connected pore networks. Furthermore, functionalization led to improved dispersion, lithium absorption/release behavior, and pozzolanic reactivity, which paved a solid path for tailoring NIC.

(ii) NIC was tailored based on the functionalized clay nanoparticles to achieve a "duplex" function: unique pozzolanic reactions and a more uniform water distribution for enhanced cement hydration. This was further upgraded to a "triplex" function by saturating the particles with lithium solutions. In the presence of NIC, higher exothermic peaks, shortened induction period, improved degree of cement hydration, and reduced apparent activation energy were triggered. A desired coupling effect of lithium and saturated MK in enhancing cement hydration was confirmed by the increased degree of cement hydration and degree of reaction of MK. Increased aluminosilicate chains, polymerization degree, precipitation of Al-rich phases, a denser mixture, and the formation of cubic siliceous hydrogarnet were observed. The work successfully linked cement chemistry with targeted ASR suppression, combining the chemical introduction of reactive minerals and ions with the creation of short-range interconnected pores as pathways for retarding ions.

(iii) To answer the fundamental hypothesis that NIC can achieve full suppression of ASR through suppressing multiple prerequisites, the role of NIC in improving the physical properties of concrete and ASR mitigation was investigated. Reduced autogenous shrinkage, increased chemical shrinkage, and improved compressive strength were triggered by NIC. The side effects of single incorporations of MK and lithium on the early-age concrete properties were addressed by combining saturated MK and lithium. The ASR expansion decreased and no cracks can be detected from the NIC groups. A sustained strength gain was observed from the NIC group even after being transferred to the hot-alkaline accelerated aging condition, which highlighted the effective ASR mitigation. Suppressed silica dissolution in the presence of lithium and aluminum and mitigated formation of expansive ASR gels in the presence of lithium and aluminum were observed. Decreased Si-O stretching and Si-O-Si deformation vibrations and fewer Q3 polymerization sites in ASR gels were obtained and the size of the layered crystalline ASR products decreased with less ordered structures and less amorphous ASR gels. The efficacy of suppressing ASR-induced expansion and cracking superior to lithium was obtained from magnesium. Magnesium was found to suppress silica dissolution and mitigate the formation of Q3 sites were mitigated. 

(iv) A solid collaboration with local K-12 schools has been established through versatile educational and outreach activities and their integration with the research works. These activities include lab tours and hands-on projects for high school students and the Engineering Design Summer Camp at UMass Lowell. Two Ph.D. students have been supported as research assistants for this project. Six MS students including two female students conducted research works related to this project. Through UMass Lowell’s “Immersive Scholar” program, four undergraduate students including two female students joined the research team and gave oral presentations for their research outcomes in the Annual Student Symposium at UMass Lowell. Three MS students graduated with theses. Two MS students and one undergraduate student served as authors for three journal papers. A new engineering course “CIVE. 5150-Cementitious Materials for Sustainable Concrete” has been developed in the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering at UMass Lowell, which has been offered twice in Spring 2020 and Spring 2023. In addition, the research findings from this project were integrated with the PI’s other courses, including CIVE.5050-Concrete Materials, CIVE.3110-Engineering Materials Laboratory, and CIVE.5040-Advanced Strength of Materials for undergraduate and graduate students through hands-on projects. The PI served as a Science and Engineering Communication Fellow at the Discovery Museum (Acton, MA) and hosted communication and presentation events for sustainable structural materials to inspire K-12 kids and their parents to enter the science and engineering fields.


Last Modified: 12/30/2023
Modified by: Jianqiang Wei
